Committee on Undergraduate
Studies member Bob Angevine at
the Student Council meeting
Wednesday night.
The proposal will likely be
voted on by the CUS in May. If
it passes, the requirement will be
put into effect in a staggered
manner.
Next year, incoming freshmen
would be required to take one intensive writing course in their
four-year term. Freshmen entering in the following year would
be required to complete two
writing courses in their term.
Ultimately, according to the proposal, Arts and Sciences students
will be required to complete four
intensive writing courses, and
engineering students will be required to complete two intensive
writing courses.

2/MARCH 31, 1989

Spring Fair gets set to head for the seas
by Bradley Cohen
The horizon appears sunny for
the arrival of Maritime '89,
scheduled to dock at Hopkins in
two weeks. Beth Friedman and
Lisa Weisbord, co-chairs of
Spring Fair, are confident that the
Fair will be a great success.
Work on organizing the Fair
began last semester with the
selection of the theme and committee assignments. Things
started to gear up over Intersession when the various food vendors, artists and entertainment
were initially contacted. Since the
start of this semester, various
committees have been working
out the details.
Both co-chairs described Fair's
progress as smooth, without any
major setbacks. "Things are
coming together really well,"
said Weisbord. "All we can do
now is hope for good weather."
In keeping with the Maritime
theme, Fair will begin with a gala

opening ceremony presided over
by reporter Tony Pagnotti of
WMAR-TV. The ceremony will
include a 21-foot boat, which
Pagnotti will christen the "USS
Hopkins."
In a break with tradition,
balloons will not be released after
the opening ceremony; instead,
school children will blow soap
bubbles as a symbolic gesture.
Friedman explained the switch,
saying that hundreds of balloons
released into the sky are bad for
the environment. "It's basically a
symbolic act," she said.
The Fair will open on the fourteenth with food vendors and
various arts and crafts booths on
the Upper and Lower Quads. An
outdoor Hoppy Hour featuring
Andy Moffit will be in the Decker
Garden.
This year will be the first that
Fair has been allowed to have
outdoor music at the Friday Hoppy Hour. Friday evening will
feature several types of entertain-

ment: the Barnstormers will be
performing "The Mystery of Edwin Drood," comedian Steven
Wright will perform a show in
Shriver Hall, and the Almighty
Senators will rock Levering Hall.
Saturday morning will begin
with an eight kilometer race
around the area. The Freshman
Quad will house the "Especially
for Kids" section, featuring small
carnival rides and games.
Saturday afternoon will be
highlighted with a United States
Coast Guard Drill Team performance on Garland Field, followed by the Fifth Annual Fair
Games. Some of the games include the "Surf and turf Relay
Race" and the "JHU America's
Cup." All teams must have five
persons and be pre-registered.
The entertainment on Saturday
includes Moffit and the mellow
tones of the Rhumba Club.
Sunday morning continues the
festivities with more food and
crafts for sale. Hopkins rugby

will be hosting arch-rival
Franklin and Marshall(who ended Hopkins's basketball dreams
this season) on Garland Field.
Following the game will be an
antique car show on the Beach.
The car exhibition will benefit
Hopkins Children's Medical and
Surgical center. Sunday will also
see former University Chaplain

Chester Wickwire hosting the annual Fair dog show.
Friedman and Weisbord are
confident that Fair will be a success. Last year the Fair attracted
nearly 100,000 persons. This
year, the Fair is hoping for more.
Friedman added, "Be sure to
come, because it's going to be
fantastic."

Stephen M. McClain,
formerly associate provost,
has been promoted to the new
position of vice provost for
academic planning and budget
at The Johns Hopkins
University.

recently by the University's
Board of Trustees, will replace
the positions of vice provost
and associate provost. The
vice provost's post had been
vacant since last summer,
while McClain had served as
associate provost since 1984.

COUNCIL, from 1
"Students should understand
that this requirement will add no
extra burden to their workload,"
said Angevine. He emphasized
that the requirement proposal
represents a joint effort on the
and
of
faculty
part
undergraduates to improve the
writing skill of undergraduates at
Hopkins.
According to Angevine, individual departments would have
a say in determining which
courses meet the proposed
writing requirements. He explained that new courses would
not have to be created in order to
proposal's
the
fulfill
requirements.
Existing courses would be able
to adapt to these requirements.
An introductory science course,
for example, could qualify as
"writing-intensive" if the professor offers structural and
stylistic criticism of lab reports
and asks for rewrites.
"We need voluntary participation," said junior Peter Blitstein,
who is also a CUS member. He
added that the CUS would form
a committee to evaluate and coordinate the program. The individual departments could then
consult this committee about
classes they wish to classify as
"writing-intensive."

Next came an update on the
status of the Catholic Community. "It looks like we're going to
have a Newman House next
year," said junior class representative Maureen Gale, copresident of the Community.
Gale then spoke about her recent trip, along with fifteen other
students, to the local Archdoicese
office, where she delivered petitions in protest of the planned
closing of Newman House. Archdiocese officials informed them
that Newman House could remain
open if more students live at the
house, pay rent, and work in the
peer ministry.
In the past, explained Gale,

Newman House residents lived
there for free and did household
chores in exchange for rent.
Gale also expressed concern
about the fate of Father John
Donahue, C.S.P., who has offered to remain at the house,
draw off his retirement fund, and
work there for free. An official
at the Archdiocese does not want
Donahue to stay, said Gale.
Other items of interest:
*The Department of History
has established a scholarship fund
in the memory of history graduate
student Bridget Phillips, who was
murdered in her apartment March
23. Council decided to make a
donation to this fund.

a minority to make himself
known, said Banks, he must take

*The sophomore class will

on April 8 to benefit the
Maryland Food Bank. Prizes will

*The freshman class will sponsor a bus trip to Washington,

Police have no witnesses, and
neighbors reported no unusual
noises in her apartment around
the time of the murder. Phillips's
apartment showed no signs of
forced entry or missing items,
though one window was open. An
officer with Northern District
police said campus security as
well as Baltimore police are investigating the murder.
A Gainesville, Fla. resident,
Phillips attended the University of
Florida, studying briefly at the
universities of Vienna and Cambridge, before coming to Hopkins
in September. She was studying
medieval and Byzantine history.
Professor John Baldwin said
that "for a young woman, she
was unusually motivated for a
highly difficult course of study."
Phillips had worked closely with
Professor Michael McCormick
and the History of Art department
on the handling of Byzantine
liturgical texts, one of the most
difficult areas of historical
studies.
Fluent in French, German, and
Latin, Phillips was in the process
of mastering Greek for her
studies. According to Baldwin,
Phillips had "made remarkable
progress with the linguistic
tools."
Troy Davis, a security guard
who lived across from Phillips's
second-floor apartment, said tha
Phillips was helpful and often
watched his child while he
worked.
A.J.R. Russell-Wood, history
chairman, said the department
has established a fellowship in her
name. A memorial service was
held for Phillips yesterday in the
Garrett Room. Funeral services
will be held tomorrow in Kansas.

FELLOWSHIP IN MEMORY OF PHILLIPS
A Bridget Bernadette
Phillips Memorial Fellowship
in Byzantine and Early
Medieval Studies is being
established at The Johns
Hopkins University to honor
the memory of the first-year
graduate student in history
who was murdered last week.
The purpose of the
fellowship will be to encourage others to enter the
field of study being pursued by
Phillips at the time of her
death, said Professor A.J.R.
Russell-Wood, chairman of

the Department of History.
"Bridget was very happy
and absorbed in her work at
Johns Hopkins," said her
father, Kelley Phillips of
Gainesville, Florida. "I and
my family would like to see
the same educational opportunity created for other young
students who share Bridget's
interest in Byzantine and
medieval history. With that in
mind, we fully support the
establishment of the Bridget
Bernadette Phillips Memorial
Fellowship."

Plans are to award the
fellowship for the first time
next year and to advertise its
availability in academic journals. Preference will be given
to an entering graduate
student.
Contributions in the
student's memory should be
addressed to the Chairman,
Department of History, 312
Gilman Hall, The Johns
Hopkins University, 34th &
Charles Streets, Baltimore,
MD 21218, and marked
"Bridget Bernadette Phillips

Memorial Fellowship."
Phillips, 22, was a former
National Merit Scholar who
graduated from the University of Florida in Gainesville.
During her undergraduate
career, she had also studied at
the Universities of Cambridge
and Vienna.
"She was exhilarated by the
sheer zest of living and
welcomed every new intellectual challenge," said RussellWood. "That her life should
have ended so tragically affects us all very, deeply."

occur if Roe were overturned.
Yard also called an ABC
News-Harris poll that found fiftyseven percent of Americans in
favor of a women's right to abortion and forty percent opposed as
a clear public mandate in favor of

News-Letter

Recognizing realities
The murder last week of graduate student Bridget Phillips has stunned
Homewood. As her friends and family
mourn their loss, the shocked community is struck by the senselessness of the
crime. That the life of one with so much
to offer the world should be ended so
brutally is an incomprehensible, terrible waste.
Phillips' death is the more unsettling
because it brings into mind our own
mortality. She was living a life very
similar to many of our own lives. She
was, after all, a student, living in
Charles Village, a neighborhood heavily
populated with Hopkins students. While
we do not know the full circumstances
of her death, it appears that such an unprovoked assault could have happened
to any one of us.
It is unfortunate that it has taken this
tragedy to forcibly turn students' attention to the issue of security. While it
may seem shocking to us that such a
tragedy could occur among us, to the
-Baltimore City Police, Phillips' death is
but a homicide statistic on a list in a
large metropolitan area. Crimes such-as
this are commonplace in this and many
other cities.
For our campus is, in fact, despite its
grassy fields and stately Georgian architecture, in a large and dangerous city. We naively view Homewood as
somehow separate from Baltimore, and

tend to view ourselves as separate from
the dangers of living here. As students
living off-campus, we see our
neighborhoods as extensions of that
idyllic haven, rather than the urban
areas that they are. This assumption
often leads to careless and reckless
behavior on our parts. For instance,
walking home drunk from parties, or
even from visiting friends late at night
is quite common. Necessary precautions
are rarely taken. If any good is to come
from the catastrophic tragedy of last
week, students must alter this perception of the city as an extension of campus, and open their eyes to dangerous
realities of urban life.
Furthermore, students cease to
perceive campus as safe from city
crime. Incidences that have happened in
the past semester point to the fact that
Homewood is just as susceptible te
violence—maybe even more susceptible, given our naivete and foolhardy
behavior.
It would not be fair, however, to warn
only students. Homewood administration must, once and for all, admit the
inadequacies of Campus Security—
especially because of these recent
incidences— and act swiftly to rectify
them. The role of apologist does not suit
the administration, and furthermore
serves no one's benefit.

The
camps
are
near
Poughkeepsie in Fishkill, set
upon several thousand acres of
rolling hills, fields and lakes.
Although there are several camps
on the reservation, one of the best
equipped and most interesting is
Hidden Valley camp. It is also
probably the most challenging.
Hidden Valley is a mixture of
emotionally and physically handicapped children and able bodied
children, falling approximately
into two age groups: 7 to 10 in
the lower ages, and 11 on up in
the other. All are at the camp free
of charge, having been recommended by social workers in their
home neighborhoods in New
York. Most come to the camp
from one parent homes, and
many have hair-raising stories to
tell of shootings and the like in
their housing complexes. A
significant few come from stable,
working poor households. The
idea is to combine handicapped
and able-bodied children in a noncompetitive atmosphere where no
one need feel left out.
You would be either a general
counselor, or, depending upon
your certification, a waterfront
supervisor and the like. Each additional piece of certification you
bring with you means a little bit
more pay for the summer(and the
pay is very reasonable), as well
as increased flexibility in your activity scheduling at camp.
The counselors are every bit as
extraordinary as the campers,
overall, and come from all over
the country and the world to work
at the camp. Last summer there
were counselors from as far away
as Ireland, England and Hong

One of the great things about
April is that you not only have the
remainder of the semester to
worry about, but also the encroaching summertime. Summer
used to be really straightforward;
you screwed around until your
parents sent you to summer
camp, or maybe worked at an ice
cream store, and then before you
knew what had happened it was
time to go back to school.
Thank goodness we now have
to worry about making lots of
money to help pay for school, as
well as concern ourselves with
the relative significance of our
employment upon a resume. Ice
Cream Service Engineer Programmer. Lawn Maintenance
Manager Executive Assistant.
A few manage to find genuinely rewarding jobs strangling rats,
skewering mice or photocopying
old letters, all in the name of
medicine, law,or what have you.
If this is the sort of excitement
your summer holds in store, and
the prospect is making exams
look a little better in a relative
kind of way, there is an alternative which may make this summer like no other, and genuinely
make a difference in your life.
The organization is called the
Fresh Air Fund. Headquartered
in New York, the Fund was
established at the beginning of
this century for the sole purpose
of getting children from the inner
city out to the healthier air and activity of the countryside for a two
week summer holiday. The
modern Fund is split between
homestays, where children are
sent to suburban, middle class
families throughout the Northeast, and the overnight camps,
icated in upstate New York.

To the Editors:

ingenuous. He points out that they
are quite up front about being. . . well. . . Republicans: I
mean, gosh, they call themselves
Republicans and everything. True
enough, but not quite to the point.
What do I mean by disingenuous
in the case of CR's? I mean that
they are involved in political
struggles, but they try to act as if
they are doing something else.
This is particularly a question of
how they present themselves.
Yes, they call themselves
Republicans, but somehow they
never talk about themselves as if
they were involed for political
reasons. You'd almost think CR's
stood for College Religionists
they way they've been wading into theological questions of late.
First they set themselves up as
authorities on what counts as
religious, and then they attack the
Chaplain for involving herself in
nonreligious activities. Ask the
CR's why they're gunning for
the Chaplain and what do they tell
you? They come back with
something about how the
Chaplain should limit herself to
religious issues. But is that why
they're gunning for the Chaplain?
No, that's the argument they're
using as a weapon in their attempt
to silence a voice they oppose for
political reasons. If the CR's
were honest they'd admit that
they don't give a damn whether
the Chaplain's positions are genuinely religious or not. All they
care about is that she stop saying
and doing things that don't cohere
with their right-wing ideology.
But they won't admit this. Instead
they cloak themselves in the mantle of religious purity. And that,
Mr. Rosen, is disingenuous.
By the way, I'm with Steve
Johnston: sign the CR's petition
because we all agree that the
Chaplain should limit herself to
religion, but oppose the CR's attempts to dictate what counts as
religion.
Note, Mr. Rosen, I stick to my
word: I have nothing further to
say on the antisemitism issue.

Despite his success as a fund
raiser, Steve Muller's problems
were, in part, a result of the
system of funding of the different
divisions. Divisional autonomy
allowed the School of Arts and
Sciences to be distressingly poor
while the Medical School was
very rich. As in some families,
the rich member was not inclined to contribute to a "bail-out"
of the poor cousin. In university
financing (as for personal credit
cards), there comes a time when
one has to "pay up." That's what
the Five-Year Plan is about.
Students are paying through increased tuition; the faculty,
especially in A&S, are paying
through smaller salary increases
and larger teaching loads. The
Divisions of Medicine, Engineering, and the Applied Pysics
Laboratory are contributing to a
reserve fund that will bring A&S
out of debtors' prison.
For my part, I like many of the
developments of the Muller
years. The more diverse
undergraduate student body is a
pleasure to teach; merging
Engineering with A&S was a
mistake—the recreated Division
of Engineering is thriving; the addition of Peabody seems to me an
excellent move for a university
long on teaching theory but lacking in "performance" opportunities for its students, especially the undergraduates.
Perhaps the new president can
solve the problems arising from
divisional autonomy without
eroding the special character of
each division; perhaps the new
president will be a wizard fund
raiser, close friend to students
and faculty, and a noted scholar;
perhaps the Orioles will win the
World Series in 1989!

Genuine French
croissants baked
at Jocelyne's
by Eric Ruck
•

The boy on the back of a bicycle on a country road, central in
the poster with the word 'France'
emblazoned across it does not attract as much attention as the two
large, crisscrossed baguettes
riding along with him. Although
one would find a similar scene out
of place in Baltimore City, Joany
Testud, owner of Jocelyne's
Bakery at 3433 Greenmount
Avenue, says this is not uncommon in his native country.
"In France we buy baguettes
every day. We have bakeries
everywhere," says Testud. He
does admit, however, that most
people travel to the store by car.
Most of the Hopkins students
familiar with Jocelyne's have
seen them at the 32d Street
Farmer's Market every Saturday
near Greenmount Avenue. According to Testud, who has taken
part in five different markets, this
one is the best, and that is why
he chose to locate his store on
Greenmount.

"I like Greenmount Avenue.
It's not a good area now, but I
think in a few years it will be a
good spot." A member of the
Better Greenmount Alliance, he
says, "I think by this association
there will be a change."
Many of the local residents
come to Jocelyne's to take advantage of the goods that are not only baked fresh daily, but tend to
be less expensive than the competition. The bakery enjoys the
patronage of 25 or 30 regular
customers, who come in daily to
buy croissants.
Although they sell mostly
breads and plain croissants, fancy croissants and pastries, and
cakes for wedding and birthdays
are also popular.
"We sell what we bake. I have
some other stuff, like pate
sausages, that a friend of mine
makes," says Testud. "I fix up
sandwiches for lunch, of pate and
sausages."
According to Testud, the
bakery's bread and butter is in the
wholesale business. He sells to

hotels and other bakeries, the
likes of Chez Fernand, Marconi's, The Bistro, and the Harbor Court Hotel.
Displaying a post card with a
typical French cafe, he regrets
that there is nothing similar in
Baltimore.
"There are some cafes like this
in New York. In France,
everybody goes once a day to
smoke, drink coffee, read the
newspaper, or talk politics."
Jocelyne's Bakery can be a bit
difficult to find. It's on the corner of 35th and Greenmount.
Although the stained glass window above the store says 'Alan
Bruce Catering' for the building's
upstairs tenant, the name of the
bakery has been added to the plate
glass window below. The store is
closed Mondays, open Tuesday
through Friday from 8 a.m. to 6
p.m., Saturday from noon until 6
p.m., and Sunday from 9 a.m.
until noon. The telephone number
is 366-7600.

A RT(A RV E D

How does Jocelyne's Bakery
stack up to the competition?
Three college students, with
nothing better to do with
themselves during spring break,
were determined to find out.
Skipping Giant and Sara Lee, the
low-life of the pastry world, they
pitted the bakery's butter croissant against the defending champion, Vie de France.
On first inspection, the Vie de
France croissant had a better
shape. Seen under good sunlight,
however, Jocelyne's entry looked
moister, and overall more
appealing.
According to one of our
panelists, "Jocelyne's smells
more buttery. To me the Vie de
France smells like bread."
Unanimously deciding that the
two contenders felt exactly like a
croissant should feel (neither of
them could be made to sound like
anything), the reviewers decided

it was time to go on to the final,
most important sense of them all:
the taste test. The croissants were
divided into careful thirds.
"This one's [Jocelyne's] is a lot
flakier, but! don't know if that's
good," said one of our more experienced members. "This other
is more bread-like in consistency.
After tasting, two of the three
panelists agreed that Jocelyne's
sample was indeed much better.
The third panelist agreed that it
was better, although he was not
so emphatic.
"If this one wasn't in my right
hand, and this in my left hand, I'd
say they taste the same."
Of course, this was the same
person who wasn't sure whether
flakiness was good. The other
panelists took up a collection
amongst themselves to send this
poor boy down the street to
McDonald's.

Babe Ruth's
Birthplace and Baltimore Orioles Museum

at the Babe Ruth
by Scott Needle
Virtually everyone has heard of
George Herman Ruth, the great
baseball player of the 1920s. But
very few Hopkins students have
heard of the Babe Ruth Museum
right here in Baltimore.
The museum, downtown at 216
Emory Street, is the actual house
in which Babe Ruth grew up. It
is actually made up of four
houses, from 212 to 218, but part
of the original Babe Ruth house
is still preserved just as young
Ruth would have remembered it.
On the second floor visitors can
see the very room where Babe
Ruth was born on February 6,
1895. Outside the room are
various photos of the legend
throughout the his life, as well as
personal mementoes like his suitcase and his team photo when he
attended St. Mary's Industrial
School. His parents sent him
away to the reform school when
he was only seven years old. It
was at the school that he learned
to play baseball.
Word of Ruth's talent spread.
In 1914 Jack Dunn, owner of the
minor league Baltimore Oribles,
signed Ruth onto the team.
Because he was only 18, he was
called Dunn's "baby," or later,
"Babe" Ruth. The museum also
has an exhibit on Jack Dunn as
well as Jack Dunn II, III, and IV,
all of whom were and are active
in Baltimore baseball in various
roles.

Babe Ruth was traded for
$3000 to pitch for the Boston Red
Sox. His contract was then sold
to the New York Yankees in 1920
for a phenomenal $125,000.
Yankee Stadium, "The House
That Ruth Built," was designed
to hold the crowds that flocked to
see the Babe hit. He set an incredible number of hitting
records before he retired from
playing in 1935. In 1936 he was
elected to the Baseball Hall of
Fame. He died of cancer in 1948.
The museum is actually called
the Babe Ruth Birthplace and
Baltimore Orioles Museum
because it contains more than just
Babe Ruth rememberances.
There is a room dedicated to the
Orioles, filled with memorabilia
since 1954, when they entered the
major leagues. There is the 1983
World Series trophy, numerous
uniforms, equipment, and awards
of players (including Jim
Palmer's Cy Young Award), as
well as the Orioles Hall of Fame
which includes Brooks Robinson,
Earl Weaver, Ken Singleton, and
other Orioles greats.
A new addition to the museum
is the brand new Orioles
uniforms. These uniforms,
reflecting the first changes in
eight years, have not even been
worn yet—they will debut on
opening day. The museum also
displays examples of the nine
previous uniforms that Orioles
have worn.
But in fact, the museum con-

"Johnny's home run" story is
just one example of this. When
Ruth heard that the young Johnny
had an incurable disease, he promised to hit a home run for him
in the next game. Ruth not only
hit one but even two more, and
Johnny miraculously recovered.
Babe Ruth became a largerthan-life legend through his
baseball, carefree attitude, love
for children, and even his size.
The museum celebrates this and
also to some extent mirrors these
things. It is dedicated to baseball
achievements, and it appears that
it loves kids, too—it was named
"Baltimore's Best Kids' Birthday
Place." But quite unlike Babe
Ruth, the museum is not very big,
and it is quite serious about the
future.
The museum underwent major
renovation and expansion in early 1983, but still needs more
space for displays on the International League (from 1904-1954),
the Negro League, and other
periods of Baltimore baseball
history. The expansion planned
down the street should pay off,
especially since the Camden
Yards Stadium planned down the
street will open in a few years.
The Babe Ruth Birthplace and
Baltimore Orioles Museum is a
fascinating place to visit, and no
one who enjoys baseball should
miss seeing it. It is located
downtown off Pratt and Greene at
216 Emory Street. Call 727-1539
for hours and admission prices.

Hopkins triumphant in particle physics
by Sharyn Horowitz
and Chris Kolda
Lab director Jack Spangler
bounds into Physics and
Astronomy department chair Dr.
J. C. Walker's office, jubilantly
exclaiming "Theyjust got Box 2!
They plugged it in and it works!"
A smile spreads across Dr.
Walker'sface. Who says physics
isn't exciting?
A small group of Hopkins
physicists have produced the
heart of one of the detectors of the
world's premier particle accelerators. The job, to design and
build the equipment for the Large
Electron-Positron Collider(LEP)
which is being built in Geneva by
CERN, fell to Hopkins after a
large team at Northeastern
University failed to produce a
workable design after six years of
trying. That was six months ago.
Since then, Dr. Aihud Pevsner,
lab director Jack Spangler, postdoc Homera Akbari, grad student
Jian-Zhong Bao, Mechnical
Engineering professor Dr. Edwin
Fitzgerald, his son Robert
Fitzgerald, engineer Joe Orndorff, technician Dave Newman,
two machine shops, and two
undergraduates, Dan Durkin and
Chris Kolda, have achieved what
seemed almost impossible around
Christmastime: to design and
construct the electronics for the
Time Expansion Chamber
(TEC), which will house and
register the results of high energy
collisions. Says Dr. Walker,
"[Their achievement] was
miraculous. . .1 didn't think they

could do it."
CERN,
the
European
Organization for Nuclear
Research, is an international
research facility in Geneva,
Switzerland. Construction of LEP
began about six years ago, with
the goal of studying the fundamental particles that make up
our universe. LEP creates beams
of fundamental particles, electrons and positrons, magnetically accelerates them around a 27kilometer circular track located
up to 100 meters underground,
and lets them collide at four sites
around the ring. The result of
these tremendously high energy
collisions is an assortment of particles that are recorded by detectors that encapsulate the collision
site. These detectors are capable
of measuring the charge, mass,
and energy of the new particles.
Physicists will analyze the data
from detectors, searching for
clues about how the universe is
held together.
High-energy physics is the
study of what are believed to be
the four fundamental forces of the
universe: the strong force, the
weak force, the electromagnetic
force, and gravity. Experiments
at CERN have shown that, at high
temperatures, where fundamental
particles have a lot of energy, the
electromagnetic and weak forces
unify to become the electroweak
force. These results have led
physicists to speculate that immediately after the Big Bang, the
explosion which is believed to
have started the universe, the
temperature of the universe was

The ninth Ferdinand G.
Brickwedde Lecture in Physics
will address "New Directions in
Securing Data Networks" at 4
p.m., April 4, in Rowland Hall
on the Homewood campus. The
speaker, Melvin Schwartz,
received a Nobel Prize in 1988
for his discovery of the muon
neutrino in 1962. He is president
and founder of Digital Pathways,
Inc., a Silicon Valley, Calif.,
computer business.

Science
in Brief
Courtesy JHMI
The Brickwedde Lectures were
made possible by a contribution
from Professor Brickwedde and
his wife, Langhorne Howard
Brickwedde. A Johns Hopkins
alumnus, Brickwedde is known
for his co-discovery of
deuterium, a heavy isotope of
hydrogen. He is currently a professor emeritus of physics at
Pennsylvania State University.

Masking tape to cure disease
A research team led by Johns
Hopkins scientists has developed
a new variation on a sort of
biochemical 'masking tape' that
attaches to genetic material and
blocks effects of specific genes.
The technique one day might be
used routinely to block leukemia,
AIDS or herpes viruses, cancerinitiating genes, or genes that go
awry in hereditary diseases. It
also can help answer more basic
questions about how specific
genes act.
The research focuses on
matagens (Masking Tape for
Gene Expression), segments of
lab-made genetic material that
bind to messenger RNA, the first
molecule a gene expresses. The
matagens' structure so complements the messenger RNA—
like a reverse image—that it is effectively blocked. Then all the
reactions a gene normally triggers
in a cell, such as formation of enzymes of cell structures, stop.

LEP collider
PHYSICS, from 16
effective. Plus, the L3 is being
built in 13 different countries by
460 different scientists. Each
piece is sent to Geneva, where
they are all assembled and
hopefully are compatible with
each other. The faster the components get to Geneva, the sooner
they can be tested, and the more
time physicists have to work out
the bugs. Consequently, the TEC
is being rushed to Geneva in
separate boxes. The chances for

error and failure are enormous.
The Hopkins team has surprised
itself by its consistent success.
LEP will be switched on
sometime this summer. The
results of the L3 experiments will
be analyzed by an international
team of physicists, including Dr.
Pevsner. Data will be transmitted
between the collaborators by a
computer network called
LEP3NET. Hopkins has a roomful of computers ready to analyze
the information when it comes in.

Matagens consist of segments
of lab-made genetic material that
complement the structure of the
messenger molecules genes produce. The matagens bind to these
messengers, effectively stopping
reactions a gene normally triggers
in a cell—production of enzymes
or cell structures.
The research team, led by Paul
Ts'o, Ph.D., has already used
matagens to block the herpes
simplex (cold sore) virus in
mouse skin and monkey and

human cell cultures by blocking
a gene found exclusively in the
virus. Matagens similarly have
halted a simian virus, vesicular
stomatitis virus, in cell cultures
from monkeys and mice, and a
rabbit gene coding for part of the
hemoglobin molecule. Experiments are still in their early
stages, says researcher Paul
Miller, Ph.D. But human applications should follow, first with
viruses such as herpes or human
T-cell leukemia, then with genes

that regulate cancer genes.
The Hopkins matagen appears
to be unique. Miller says, in overcoming a number of the
obstacles. Chemists designed it to
be similar enough in structure to
true genetic material to bind with
it, but different enough to resist
enzyme digestion. The matagen is
also able to penetrate cell membranes to reach target gene
products.
Courtesy of JHMI News and
Infimnation.

Pre-meds to face a new
set of exam standards
MCAT, from 16
since the student will be inundated with scientific information
in medical school. A humanities
background may make the future
physician more sensitive to the
surrounding world,
Dr. John Gryder, advisor to the
pre-medical students at Hopkins,
says that the exam will be "a
more general exam, less dependent on memorization, and more
on reasoning." Gryder adds that
although the new MCAT will
comprise a smaller proportion of
science, students will still be required to take the same science
courses for admission into
medical school.
AAMC officials hope that the
new exam will reward students
who choose to take alternative

paths toward a career in
medicine, and convince the
history and economics majors
that their background does not exelude them from medicine.
Previously, the MCAT had six
sections: biology, chemistry,
physics, science problems,
reading comprehension (usually
of a scientific nature) and quantitative analysis (the reading and
analysis of information presented
in various graph forms). In addition, over the past few years, an
experimental, ungraded essay
section was included.
The new exam will have only
four secions: biological sciences,
physical sciences, verbal reasoning, and a writing sample. The
writing sample will consist of two
graded, 30-minute essays on
topics like "In matters of principle, stand like a rock; in matters

of taste, swim with the current."
The essays will be assigned letter grades, making it harder for
admissions committees to ignore
the writing, or to include it in the
student's overall score. The rest
of the exam will still be graded
numerically. The new verbol
reasoning section will evaluate
the applicant's ability to think and
argue logically.
Dr. Gryder says that the mosi
significant aspect of the new ex
amwill be the graded essay. He
says that in the past medical
schools have taken a student's
writing and organizational
abilities into account by way of
applications, essays, and personal
interviews. Now, explains
Gryder, through the new MCAT,
schools will have a standardized
way to compare students'
abilities.

in the volume. Since the later
stories use the same characters
over and over again, one could
almost say that it is like a novel.
Each individual story is so static
and slow-moving, however, that
it would never work within the
context of a novel.
Marcel Proust comes to mind
while reading a Brodkey story.
There is that intimate voice of the
self, the somber solipsism that
enables the narrator to find depth
and significance in a simple
event—falling off a bike, being
held in a father's arms. Brodkey
shares the ability to record and
recollect the images, the smells,
and the feelings of a young,
hypersensitive child.
What differentiates Brodkey's
work from Proust's is his attention to tone of voice. Whereas
Proust manages to extinguish the
outside world from his consciousness through his maze of
neverending
introspective
sentences. Brodkey never loses
sight of it; most of these narratives are told in an intense first
pe.-son. (Hence the title for my
favorite story, "Largely an Oral
History of My Mother.")
Strangely, the narrator never
speaks for himself, only listens.
Brodkey recombines the bits and
pieces of speech and dialogue of
his parents with a helpless honesty that will be painful to read for
any person who has any memory
of childhood. And if Brodkey
must be admired for anything, it's

Brodkey's Modes
BRODKEY, from 18
little more than portraits, attempts
to provide idiolect with hundreds
of pieces of dialogue, all in present tense, none in chronological
order. There is no progression in
plot or conflict, only a rising in
intensity (Don't get me wrong;
this is not bad. But you will take
a lot of snack breaks during these
stories—this I can promise you).
Or how's this for mixed
metaphors: "When I was young,
I saw people as sheer appetites,
fish leaping for flies, smooth,
beautiful and hungry. But I was
perhaps appetiteful myself then.
I'm older now and I see people
as complex things, held in and
mysterious, streaked with virtues
and ridiculous vices; I see them
perched on time, each on a breaking branch the buds of which are
sticky, new always, ready to unfold into green moments."
Sometimes in his attempt to be
lyrical, I think Brodkey falters.
So concerned is he with producing adept prose and flighty
metaphors and similes that
sometimes it seems he forgets that
stories focus around characters.
In his attempt to describe the different faces of a multi-sided diamond, he seems to have neglected
to consider the diamond as an entire entity. The result is that
Brodkey requires his readers to
be hugely patient.
But alas, I regret to confess that
I have read the book in the wrong
way. I read it from start to finish,
one story after another, anxious
to get to the end of the book. Each

story should be read individually, spaced a week or even a
month apart from each other. The
pleasure that Brodkey's prose
imparts is the pleasure of lingering, of waiting, of never looking
to the end.

Samuel Barber's "Concerto for
Cello and Orchestra" has an interesting history. During a recording session led by the composer
in 1950, one of the cellists in the
orchestra was so overcome by the
playing of the soloist, Zara
Nelsova, that he leapt up, ran to
the podium, and smashed his
cello to bits. The stunned composer and soloists heard him
shout that he would give up music
and stop playing after such a
performance.
It turned out that the scene was
a joke staged by the cello section,
a tribute to the difficulty of the
piece. The destroyed cello had

been purchased at a pawn shop as
a prop.
While nothing so dramatic took
place during the Baltimore Symphony's recording sessions of the
same work last year, the exciting
interpretation of the piece by
cellist Yo-Yo Ma may very well
arouse the admiration and emotions of the listener.
Those who purchase the newlyreleased compact disc will hear a
sometimes playful, sometimes intense interpretation in which each
phrase has a carefully individuated character. The cadenzas are played with sparkle and
brilliance. Large leaps in the
melody melt into rolling,
sculptured passagework. From
the gentle, singing theme of the
second movement to the almost
raucous, defiant third movement,
Ma is absorbed in the music, as
if telling a story with his bow.
David Zinman's direction of
the orchestration is thoughtful,
accurate, and in perfect keeping
with Ma's immersion in the
music. Tempos are well-chosen
for the strident orchestral
statements, and there is a wonderful melding of ensemble textures.
The difficulty of Barber's concerto may be the reason it is rarely played and even less frequently recorded. This CD,the first of
the BSO on the prestigious CBS
label, also contains another
scarecely-recorded work, Benjamin Britten's "Symphony for
Cello and Orchestra."
The symphony was written in
1963 and dedicated to Mstislav
Rostropovich, who gave the first
performance in Moscow the
following year. Like the Barber
concerto, it is a modern work in

7 unanswered goals and 3rd-quarter shutout lead Hopkins past Princeton, 11-5
by Patrick Furey

team continued to roll last
weekend, exploding for seven

Baseball enjoys Southern hospitality
by Josh Orenstein
The Hopkins baseball team
(11-3) has returned from a highly
successful southern trip with
championships at both the Sanford and University Athletic
Association tournaments.
"I am very pleased with our
performance," said head coach
Robert Babb. "We are getting
good fielding, good pitching, and
timely hitting."
After opening the trip with a
13-1 loss to Methodist, the Blue
Jays proceeded south to Florida,
where they captured seven of
eight games in the Sanford Tournament at Wes Rinker's Baseball
School. The Blue Jays earned the
best record of any team competing in the tournament during
their five days of competition.
The next stop was Atlanta,
where Hopkins captured the
University Athletic Association
title. The Jays went 4-1 to boast
the best record of the five teams
competing in the round-robin
tournament.
After returning to Baltimore,
the Jays traveled to Westminster
March 28, where they defeated
Western Maryland College, 11-6.
Junior Ian Gaisford pitched six
innings and gave up only three
hits and one earned run to win his
second game of the season. The

Jays totalled sixteen hits, seven
for extra bases, including a triple
by junior Ron Lewis and
sophomore Pete Kwiterovich's
third home run.
"I didn't expect us to be 11-3,"
said Babb. "Our infield defense
has been a big part of our success." The heart of the Jays' infield is the double-play duo of
secondbaseman Andy Bernstein
and shortstop Jim Timmerman.
The two juniors were second
team all-Middle Atlantic
Conference-Southern Division
selections last season.
"Jim Timmerman is the best
defensive shortstop I've ever seen
at our level. He's the best ever at
Hopkins," said Babb. Timmerman has also been swinging a
very hot bat. In fourteen games,
he has twenty hits, including
three home runs, fourteen batted
in, and a .392 batting average.
Bernstein's hitting has been
even more potent. The secondbaseman has twenty-one hits,
fourteen RBI's, and a .457
average. Although he has been
charged with five errors this
season, (as many as he accumulated in 35 games last year),
Babb is unconcerned, deeming
them "lack of concentration" errors. Timmerman and Bernstein
have turned fourteen double plays
in fourteen games.

Pete Kwiterovich, Mike Zehring, and Ron Lewis have also
been central to the Jays' offensive
success. Kwiterovich, the starting
catcher, has thirteen hits, eleven
RBI's, and a .317 batting
average. Leadoff hitter Zehring,
an outfielder, has nineteen runs
scored, fourteen hits, and twelve
RBI's, and is batting .333. Outfielder Lewis has ten hits and a
.370 batting average.
The team's pitching depth has
also pleased Babb. "Jason
Klitenac is pitching with a world
of confidence. He has thrown
great pitches at great times. He
now has the ability to throw
strikes with his change up." The.
senior lefthander, possessing a
4-0 record and a 0.71 earned run
average, has become Babb's ace.
Freshman Jeff Fang has emerged as the number two start&
Fang has won both of his stalls,
and sports a 1.13 ERA. Junior
Scott Tarantino, the team's captain, is the top reliever.
Saturday, the Jays play their
first MAC Southeast Section
games, as Widener visits
Homewood for a noon
doubleheader. The homestead
File Photo

Dickinson visits for a single The Johns Hopkins baseball team got off to a fast start on their trip
game.
through the South. The Blue Jays captured the UAA Championship in
Atlanta and the trophy for their week's stay at the Sanford Tournament.
Their record currently stands at 11-3.

The meet, however, became
more than a normal competition
to the Hopkins team on Saturday
night as two events epitomized
both ends of the performance
spectrum. In the first event of the
night, the top heat of the 1650
Freestyle, Stephanie Dengler was
seded third. Due to its length, this
event is the only one of the meet
which does not include both
preliminary and final heats.
Dengler prepared for the event
and was in high spirits after two
previous top-8 performances.
The race began with no glitches,
and Dengler later said it felt like
the best mile of her career.
However, at the 625-yard mark,
disaster struck. Dengler, unable
to breathe, struggled to the end of
the pool as worried teammates
looked on. As she was pulled out
of the pool, the race continued
around her. Dengler, unable to
feel her feet or see, was suffering from hyperventilation—an
unusual but all too frightening occurrence for swimmers. As she
was taken to a side room on a
backboard by paramedics, the
race finished and the meet continued. Hopkins's swimmers continued to put in lifetime-best performances, and Stephanie
returned to the poolside just
in time to cheer on the most
outstanding performance of
the meet.
Anne Marie Largay had defied
the odds by even being at this
meet. All season she had battled
a shoulder injury, but had continued to train as much as was
allowed. Only twelve weeks

earlier, she had undergone
surgery in an attempt to correct
the problem and had been in a full
training schedule for only a fraction of that time. Entering the
200- Yard Butterfly, the last individual event of the meet,
Largay confessed that she would
be happy with anything above a
sixth place finish. What she accomplished was much more that
that. With a time of 2:08.91,
sophomore Anne Marie Largay of
Bath, Maine, captured first place
and became the National Cham-

Men's track qualifies 8 for MACs
by Mark Melia
The future is now. This is the
only appropriate way to describe
the 1989 men's track team.
The future of the men's track
team seems phenomenal as eight
underclassmen qualified for the
Middle Atlantic Championship in
the first meet of the season. The
qualifiers
were:
Forrest
Closson-200M,
Manny
Hostin-800M,
John
Robinson-1500M,
Matt
Hannon-400M hurdles, Glenn
Sabin-shot put, Eric Hastingsjavelin, Tom Brennan-pole vault,
and Max Psolka-triple jump. This
year's team has already qualified
more individuals for the championships in one meet than last
year's team in the entire season,
and last year's team won four of
ten meets. Although the Jays did
lose their first meet on Wednesday to Franklin & Marshall, the
prospects for a successful season
are, obviously, not unwarranted.

tory in the 800M with a time of
2:01. Distance coach Jim Grogan
commented, "Something went
right. I'm not sure what, but I'm
ecstatic anyway! Now, if I had
only picked Seton Hall.
The sprint team had a rough
outing against a well-prepared
F&M squad. Nevertheless, Forrest Closson managed a win in the

200M run with a time of 23.3
seconds. Matt Hannon used the
strength of the F&M hurdlers to
pull him along to MAC qualification despite his third place finish
in the 400M hurdles. The other
bright spot for the team was the
performance of the mile relay
team,which missed qualifying by
only five seconds.

Last season, the Blue Jays fell
to Roanoke 13-9 in the regular

The Blue Jays opened the
season March 14 with a decisive
25-6 victory over the College of
Notre Dame. Hart and Herring

Jays played host to MAC-foe
Washington College and dumped
the Shorewomen 13-5. Junior
Patty Lagator (Timonium, MD)

Since defeating Roanoke, the
Blue Jays have maintained their
unblemished record with a
decisive 20-5 victory over
Plymouth State Monday night.
Nine Blue Jays recorded goals in
the contest, led by Lagator, who
scored four.

leads all Hopkins scorers with
thirteen goals and eight assists for
twenty-one points. Hart is second
with thirteen goals and one assist
for fourteen points. The Blue Jays
now enter the Middle Atlantic
Conference(MAC)portion of the
schedule as they face Haverford
today, Dickinson (4/4)and travel
to Gettysburg (4/6).

Men's tennis remains winless
by Andy Prior
With Tuesday's loss to Catholic
University, the men's tennis
team's record fell to 0-3. The
Jays are a relatively young squad
this season, though, and continue
to improve.
The Jays opened their season at
Loyola on Tuesday, March 14,
with a 6-3 loss. Hopkins' Lorin
Engquist defeated Tony Frontera
in straight sets, 7-6, 7-0, 6-4, at
first singles, and Francois
Erasmus came back to defeat
Loyola's Chris Saumell 4-6, 6-3,
6-4 at sixth singes. Hopkins' Sean
Graham was narrowly defeated
by Bart Kelly in fourth singles
play, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (7-4).
On Friday, March 17, Hopkins
hosted Drew, dropping that
match 8-1. Graham pulled out a
win over Drew's Chip Miller
with two narrow tie-breakers,
3-6, 7-6 (7-5), 7-6 (7-5), saving
the Jays from a shutout.
Tuesday's 6-3 loss to Catholic
University came down to the
Jays' inexperience in the third set
of three singles matches, according to Coach Bill Nelson.
Holzman tried to come back with

a second-set tie-breaker, but
CU's Andy Heckenberger held
on in the third set to take the second singles match, 6-4,
6-7(8-6), 6-3. Graham jumped
out in the first set at fourth
singles, but a tie-breaker in the
second set allowed Catholic's
Brian Caughlin to rally in the
third set for a 3-6, 7-6(7-5), 6-3
win. The Jays' Erasmus could not
convert his second-set victory into a match win, dropping at fifth
singles to Bill Sallivy, 6-0, 4-6,
6-4. Engquist defeated CU's
Michael Rave in straight sets,
7-5, 6-1, and combined with
Holzman in first doubles to win
out over Rave and Brennan in a
pro set, 8-1. Jon Missner and
Graham defeated Heckenberger
and Dave Grogan in the second
doubles match 8-3 in a pro set.
According to Coach Nelson,
the Jays are a young squad, with
just one senior and no junior
players. Three sophomores and
four freshmen complete the
roster. Despite this inexperience,
Coach Nelson claims that his
team has shown improvement
since the Spring Break, pointing
out the match against Catholic

University as a turning point for
the team.
This season's squad is led by
senior Jon Holzman, who plays
second singles, with sophomore
Lorin Engquist holding the first
singles slot. The two combine for
first doubles play. Sophomore
Jon Missner, sophomore Sean
Graham, freshman Ted Roth, and
freshman Francois Erasmus fill
out the remaining singles slots, in
that order. The second and third
doubles have been filled variously
from among them.
Engquist has been the most
consistent player, with a personal
record of 2-1, dropping his only
match to Drew. He, Holzman,
Missner, and Graham are the
backbone of the team, says Coach
Nelson. Graham's 1-2 record is
misleading because of losses in
three-set matches due to tiebreakers.
The Jays will play in the
Towson State Tournament this
weekend. The team hosts
Widener April 5 at 3 p.m. and
travels to Haverford April 8.
These latter two matches will be
the team's first MAC matches.

BIA droppings
by Cary Yeh
Welcome back folks! With only one month to go we are approaching the homestretch.
Before the break, the Badminton Tourney was won by Clark
dorm. By winning its second consecutive BIA event, Clark is closing the gap on first place
Gildersleve. Vincent/Willard
placed second, followed by
WilsoiPand McCoy. In Division
I play, Phi Psi extended its lead
over the field by defeating Kappa Sig in the finals. Third and
fourth were taken by SAM.
The billiards tournament was
also played before the break, and
Adams snapped a BIA drought by
winning it all. McCoy placed second, Gildersleve third, and
Royce/Sylvester fourth. In Division I, Phi Psi defeated SAM in
the finals for another tournament
victory. TEP finished third and
fourth.
On to new business. . . the
Foosball Tournament will be held
this weekend, April 1 and 2. The
draw will be posted TODAY.
Any questions? Call Cary at
366-1449. The LAX season is
finally here. Look for the
schedule on the board. Softball
season is also here. Sign up by
TODAY. A schedule for next
week will be posted by Sunday
morning.
Attention all BIA fanatics: Do
you want to be behind the scenes?
Do you want to make a difference? The BIA is looking for
new members. Applications are
at the CAGE. Interviews will be
held on April 18.

Next week's special BIA event
will be the track meet to be run
on Sunday. Gotta run!

After the Scarlet Knights again
cut the Jays' lead to one, the game
was delayed for an hour due to

regroup and then outscored

seal a 10-6 victory. Jeff Ihm again

with his second consecutive
three-goal game. Brendan Kelly
had two goals, and John Wilkens
added a goal and three assists for
Hopkins.
Princeton (Sat., March 25 at
Homewood)—The Blue Jays
scored seven unanswered goals in
the second half, including four
within 1:41 in the fourth quarter,
to break a 3-3 half time tie. The
11-5 victory was Hopkins's
twenty-third in a row over the
Tigers and extended their regular
season winning streak to thirteen
games.
The Jays grabbed a quick 2-0
lead in the first half on goals by
freshman Adam Wright and
sophomore Matt Panetta. But the
rest of the half belonged to the
Tigers, as they controlled the ball
and outscored Hopkins 3-1 to tie
the game at the intermission.
Without Brendan Kelly, who was
suspended for the first half along
with Greg Kelly for disciplinary
reasons, the Blue Jays had trouble getting into their offense and
dealing with Princeton's zone
defenses.

Last shots
RIFLE, from 20
ammunition instead of the match
grade rifle shells, they were again
concerned that the year's worth
of practice leading to the match
had been for naught. Fortunately, they were able to strike a lastminute trade with the team from
Army, who for some reason was
willing to take bad bullets off our
hands and give Johns Hopkins the
high quality rounds that would be
needed in a match like this.
The twenty shots fired in
Prone went off very well for all
four of the Hopkins shooters,
which can be attributed in part to
the good ammunition that
Hopkins received from Army.
Standing position hurt Hopkins
badly, as senior Neil Seidman
began to lose control and the
other members produced only
marginally good scores. In
Kneeling position, however,
Hopkins made up ground and
finished the match with an impressive team total of 1984
points. Junior Jim Kielkopf once
again led the team with a score of
529 out of 600 possible points.
Team captain Matthew Mayr produced a personal record high of
510. Neil Seidman and junior
Larry Young made a strong
showing with 485 and 460 points
each. Unfortunately, Philadelphia
College of Pharmacy and Science
came from nowhere this year
with a strong team and edged out
Johns Hopkins for first place by
scoring 70 points higher in the
team totals.
Next year, Hopkins should be
able to field an even better rifle
team. Only senior Neil Seidman
will be lost to graduation, and
Matthew Mayr has made
phenomenal improvement this
year and will be able to make up
for the loss. Matt Fischer is looking ready to take his place as a
starter, and rookies Chris Engel
and freshman Tom Steck are
becoming strong shooters as well.
The day finished as the team
pummeled their stomachs with
greasy sausage grinders from a
dirty sandwich shop off the MIT
campus and boarded the returning flight to Baltimore.

NEWS-LITTER/5

Forfeitures

A&S mortgaged to fund supercollider
The Department of Physics announced that the University
would mortgage the School of
Arts and Sciences in order to fund
the construction of a supercollider
particle accelerator near Geneva,
Switzerland.
Construction on the accelerator, which will cost approximately $14 million, or about half
of the medical school's budget
surplus, is scheduled to begin immediately. After intense bidding
by several major firms, the project was contracted to Eddie's
Supercolliders. Sources inside the
News-Letter have denied rumors
that the Eddie's conglomerate
threatened to stop supplying beer
for the Quiz if they did not get the
contract.
Asked about the financial situasoon-to-be-late-andtion,
lamented University President
Steven Muller said that the time
was just right.
The financial market is strong
right now," he said. "Thanks to
our intensive fund-raising efforts,
the chances of forfeiture are slim,
really. Besides, for an insolvent
university division, we got an excellent interest rate."
The loan was made by the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corpora-

tion, the same company that
sponsored the "space chicken"
project in which eggs were allowed to mature in orbit in the space
shuttle.
The second phase of this project calls for the development of
a low-gravity breading product,
by which the Colonel's extracrispy chicken could be created in
space.
Should the University default
on the loan, however, Kentucky
Fried Chicken can assume ownership of the School. Should this
happen, KFC spokesman Lt.
Rhett Butler said students should
not be concerned about any major changes.
"Of course there'd be some
changes in the food service
around these heya parts," he
said. "Only minor change in the
academics. For instance, we do
want the philosophy to come up
with an answer to that chicken
and egg question."
Other proposed changes would
be a country music department at
the Peabody, and a change to the
University's motto. Under new
ownership it would become,
"Y'all donate money back now,
y'heah?"
Physics Professor Gordon

Feldman insisted that the University needs a particle accelerator to
stay competitve in the 1990s. He
said that such a device, which
takes a few teensy-weensy little
particles and smashes them apart
into bunches of even smaller
pieces, is necessary for studying
subatomic particle physics. It also
grinds great coffee, and it is the

best way known to pull apart
things accidentally superglued
together.
According to Muller, the
choice of Geneva as the location
for the collider had nothing to do
with making Hopkins visible in
the European community.
"I think we own enough of
Baltimore as it is, so I didn't want

to build it here," he said. "And
after a while you get sick of sunny beaches and palm trees, so we
kept the project away from the
tropics. We picked Geneva for its
access to Alps skiing, and
because we like that variety of
Pepperidge Farm cookie."

Attention!
Students' cars for sale
There will be a sale of vehicles
repossessed around the Hopkins
campus tomorrow. The cars, left
parked at expired meters or overnight in gated lots, were owned
mostly by Hopkins students,
although some of them belonged
to faculty and campus visitors.
Chief Security Officer Robert
Larkin said, "When someone
parks illegally we put a boot on
their car and they can't move it.
Then we mail them a parking
citation, but by the time the post
office delivers it the daily fines
are so high that we just keep the

car."
A wide variety of vehicles is
available, from compact Toyotas
to roomy Oldsmobiles..They are
expected to span all price ranges,
from about $400 for a 1978 Super
Beetle to as much as $35,000 for
a black Mercedes that used to
have diplomatic license plates.
"I've gotten a number of good
deals there myself," said Senior
Vice President for Administration
Eugene Sunshine. "Just yesterday I picked up a 280-ZX for my
boy, who'll need a car to get to
UMBC next year."

All vehicles are sold 'as is'.
Th-e vehicles will be available for
inspection at 9 a.m. on the
Garland lot, and they will be auctioned off starting at 10 a.m. A
ten percent cash deposit is due at
the time of sale, with the balance
due within two business days.
As a special bonus, purchasers
get to keep anything they find in
the cars. On account of this, the
Garland lot will be closed until
noon. Any vehicles on the lot
after 8 a.m. will be booted.

IDLIJ LEELLU
Scientists are puzzled about
a phenomenon that has been
occurring on campus recently.
The disembodied head of Ira
Remsen has been speaking to
occupants of the men's room
in the basement of Remsen
Hall.
Apparently, Remsen has
been heard shouting, "Boycott
Diet Coke—it's got Nutrasweet, not saccharin!"
Researchers have no explanation for the sporadic
occurrences.
Dr. leane Dixon claimed
that it is possible that
Remsen's ashes, located on
the second floor, somehow
seeped into the plumbing.
"On his birthday, this past
February, Remsen asked for a
cake. It was fascinating."
When pressed for more information, Dixon said, "All I
can say is that Steven Muller
is going to have a very bad
year."

INCOVENIENTLY LOCATED IN ANOTHER STATE

Hockey hacker hits hi
by John Van Dingo
Senior defenseman Marc
Koren became the first college
hockey player in history to
receive the coveted Dave Schultz
Award for the second consecutive
season. He will be honored at a
ceremony between the second and
third periods of the Division I
Championship game this week.
The Schultz Award is given annually by the Philadelphia Flyers
to the dirtiest player in college
hockey. Flyer General Manager
Bobby Clarke established the
award four years ago to honor
Dave Schultz, who once logged
407 penalty minutes in a single
season, more than any other
player in NHL history while playing for the great Philadelphia
teams of the seventies.
"We try to find the player who
best embodies the Flyer spirit,"
said Philadelphia spokesman

Chris McCormick. "We don't
care about skating or stick handling skills. We're looking for a
guy who can go out there and intimidate opponents by inflicting
severe pain. Mr. Koren was our
unanimous choice for the second
straight year."
Committee members cited
Koren's unique use of his stick
and his reckless nature on the ice
as the key factors that separated
him from the other candidates for
the award. Koren has also been
kicked out of more games than
any other player in NCAA
history.
Not only is Koren the first
player to win back-to-back
Schultz Awards, but he is the only member of a club hockey team
ever to receive the award. He was
recently honored in his hometown
of Portland, Maine with a parade
and the key to the city.

Games, the only collegiate intramural competition in Charles
Village whose events all
somehow revolve around dorm
life.
All dormitories, fraternities,
and independents are eligible to
compete for the five grand prizes
offered by departments on campus. The winners of the fourweek event, which begins Sunday, will be the teams with the
highest cumulative score in the
events. Each event's winner gets
fifteen points, second place gets
twenty-one points, third gets
thirty-two, and so on.
The first two events will take
place in the Terrace Room. Contestants will be asked to stack dirty plates as high as they can, and
put them on the conveyor belt.
They will also be asked to mix
together totally unrelated foods
and to slide their concoctions off
their plates and onto the conveyor
belt.
Double points will be awarded
to the plate-stacking and foodmixing teams whose creations
elicit the loudest yelps from the
workers in the kitchen. Bonus
points will be awarded if a
worker says something about
Johns Hopkins that's not very
nice.
After that labor-consuming
event, teams will want to do
something much, much easier.
The second event calls for contestants to remove as many tables
and chairs from the cafeteria as

possible without arousing the
suspicions of the cafeteria
workers. Whoever can move the
most in thirty minutes wins.
Anyone who tries to bribe the
workers into looking the other
way is wasting time.
Event Number 3 is the Andrea
Perry Pinata Contest, in honor of
a woman who takes much more
abuse than she deserves and
smiles
it.
through
(Awwwww.
. . . .)Team members
will be blindfolded and be
to swat at their pinata with the
housemaster of their choice. The
first team to down its pinata wins.
The fourth event will be the
Great Fire Alarm Competition.
Teams will be asked to pull as
many fire alarms as possible in
the dorms in sixty seconds. The
winning team will be the one that
can draw a combination of the
most fire trucks and the most
curses from firemen when they
find out they've been had. Bonus
points will be awarded if Al
Sanders smiles with the other half
of his mouth when he reads this
story on Channel 13.
The final event is called
Housemaster Appreciation.
Teams will be asked, one each
day, to wake up each housemaster
at 4 a.m. at his door, not over the
phone. Each team will have to
come up with a typical freshman
excuse for waking up his
housemaster at that hour. The
team that can present the most
black eyes to the judges wins.
A tie-breaking event, to be held
on May I if necessary, will site
teams in several Building A

rooms. Teams will be asked to
take photographs of men and
women in the AMR II bathrooms
who don't seem to be aware that
the bathrooms have windows.
Judges will award prizes based on
the number and clarity of
photographs submitted. Sorry,
photos can't be returned.
The BIA wishes to thank the
wonderful campus organizations
who have generously provided

the prizes for the event. To build
the suspense, we will list the
prizes from fifth to first, knowing you won't skip to the end.
Fifth prize: A genuine, twocolor, Faber-Castell eraser,
graciously provided at cost by the
Bookstore.
Fourth Prize: A signed, blackand-white passport photo of Chris
Colombo, provided by the Office
of the Dean of Homewood

Schools Services.
Third prize: An abridged copy
of War and Peace, from the
housemasters.
Second prize: An exclusive dinner with the Terrace Room director behind those mysterious doorways in the Terrace Room, provided by Seiler's.
First prize: An empty hat, from
the School of Arts and Sciences.

This article is an inside joke,
so don't even bother reading it
by Frank McClannahan
The college sports world is
buzzing over rumors that John
"Buttsteak" Keating may decide
to redshirt and return to Johns
Hopkins in the fall.
In high school, Keating was a
three-sport star at Iona Prep in
New York and was offered football scholarships by Michigan and
Penn State. However, he signed
a letter of intent in December of
his senior year to attend
Louisville and play basketball.
Only two weeks later, Keating
suffered a shoulder injury while
lifting weights at the local
YMCA. Doctors said he would
never play sports again, and so he
enrolled at Hopkins in the fall of
1985.
Sports Illustrated recently
revealed that Keating underwent
surgery on his shoulder in New
York this February and is currently enrolled in a physical

therapy program at Union
Memorial Hospital in Baltimore.
Furthermore, reports have it that
Keating has been seen secretly
running and training in a secluded area about two miles north of
the Hopkins campus.
Although Keating vehemently
denies the reports, the Hopkins
students are convinced that Buttsteak will be back next year. In
fact, his roommates are rumored
to be charging admission to view
the bone chip that was removed from Keating's shoulder
in February. The proceeds are
supposedly going to the Where Is
John Foundation, a club designed to keep track of the constantlymobile Keating's whereabouts.
As a senior at Iona in 1984-85,
Keating shattered national passing
records as he quarterbacked the
Gaels to an 8-1 season (the only
loss came in the Turkey Bowl
against New Rochelle on
Thanksgiving Day). On the

basketball court. Buttsteak was
touted as the nation's top point
guard before his weight-lifting accident. He was also a star pitcher
on the Gaels' baseball team.
Keating would make an immediate impact on the Athletic
Department at Hopkins, especially in football. With Buttsteak at
quarterback, the Blue Jays could
go from 1-9 to conference champions in one season. He may also
give the basketball team the boost
it needs to emerge as a national
power.
"He's one of the most extraordinary athletes I've ever seen,"
said Michigan Athletic Director
Bo Schembechler. "He's got
unbelievable speed and a great
arm. The only reason more
schools didn't go after him was
because of rumors about steroid
use. It was a shame about his
shoulder, but if he can recover
even 50 percent, he'll be the
finest passer in Division III."

documents from Steven Muller's office and must
be sent by FAX, though we don't have a FAX
machine. Submit entries for disposal by the day
after intended publication. Call 976-CHAT if you're
confused. We are.

Anyone who knows how to
rescue a sinking ship should
call the Spring Fair office at
X7692 within two weeks.
The Progressive Student
Union will be setting fire to
some fish outside Levering Hall
to protect a persecution only we
can understand.

to play "The Star-Spangled
Banner" on key at lacrosse
games. Instead we will play
Olivia
Newton
John's
"Hopelessly Devoted to You."
Anyone who knows the song
can join.

The Student Council is looking
for potential members with a
few good ideas so that our
agendas can have a few good
ideas on them.

Do you love Hopkins? Has
every professor you've ever
had been superb? Then you're
just what we need at the Course
Guide, the only campus
publication whose members get
paid by professors. And it
shows.

Do you think you're a
benevolent scumbag? Then
come to work for First National
Bank of Maryland, where we
will teach you not only how to
make money for other people,
but also how to take money
from other people, with a smile.
